Fig. 3 Perspective drawing of the contents and coordination spheres for the asymmetric unit of ReS2 viewed down the a ¯ axis. Re⋯Re distances less than 2.90Å are represented by open bonds [taken from Ref. [23]]. Fig. 4 HTREM of Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts sulfided under: (a) H2S/H2 and (b) H2S/N2 atmosphere. Fig. 5 Relative thiophene HDS activity of unsupported (a) and γ-Al2O3 supported (b) Mo, W and Re catalysts [taken from Refs. [2] and [28], respectively]. Fig. 6 Relative thiophene HDS (a) and quinoline HDN (b) activity of Mo, W and Re sulfides supported over carbon [taken from Refs. [4] and [39], respectively]. Fig. 7 The sulfiding scheme of crystalline Re compounds [taken from Ref. [31]]. Fig. 8 The influence of H2O on the structure of the oxidic Re7+ monolayer species. For the sake of simplicity, the electrons are localized in covalent bonds (full lines), while remaining interactions are given as dotted lines [taken from Ref. [31]]. Fig. 9 The sulfiding of the oxidic Re7+ monolayer species. For the sake of simplicity, the electrons are localized in covalent bonds (full lines), while remaining interactions are given as dotted lines [taken from Ref. [31]]. Fig. 10 Effect of the calcination before sulfidation over thiophene HDS activity [taken from Ref. [16]]. Fig. 11 Influence of the rhenium content over HDS activity for Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts sulfided under H2S/N2 mixture [taken from Ref. [16]]. Fig. 12 Effect of the nature of the support and calcination over HDS of thiophene [taken from Ref. [32]]. Graphical abstract Has been observed that rhenium sulfides was among the most active transition metal and sometimes better than industrial catalyst for thiophene hydrodesulfurization and quinoline hydrodenitrogenation. Literature data published mainly during the two last decades and dealing with the preparation, structure and catalytic activities in hydrotreating reactions with rhenium sulfide has been reviewed. These compounds have been particularly evaluated in model compounds reactions as thiophene hydrodesulfurization and quinoline hydrodenitrogenation. In both cases it has been observed that rhenium sulfide was among the most active transition metal sulfides (TMS) and sometimes better than industrial CoMo/Al2O3 and NiMo/Al2O3, the sulfiding conditions appearing to be a crucial step to get highly active catalysts as previously observed for ruthenium sulfide based catalysts. Interest in these catalysts is maintained for real feed in gas oil hydrodenitrogenation reaction (HDN), even if the promoting effect induced by Co or Ni is low compared with classical molybdenum catalysts. Keywords Rhenium Sulfide Hydrotreating 1 Introduction The catalysis literature contains numerous examples of reactions that display periodic maxima or volcano relationships. Sinfelt [1] has reviewed broad relationship between catalytic activity of various metals in hydrogenation, hydrogenolysis, isomerization, hydrocarbon oxidation and ammonia synthesis–decomposition reaction and their position in periodic table. Such volcano curves have been also reported for transition metal sulfides which have been widely studied in the last 25 years due to their important industrial application as catalysts for hydrodesulfurization (HDS), for hydrodenitrogenation (HDN) and for hydrogenation (HYD) reactions [2–5]. The screening of the HDS and hydrogenation properties of various transition metal sulfides (TMS) shows that group VIII metal sulfides of the first row are poorly active whereas those of second and third rows display the maximum HDS activity. In 1981 Pecoraro and Chianelli [2] proposed that in general HDS activity correlated with the TMS enthalpy of formation. Later, relationships between HDS/HYD activity and intrinsic properties have been proposed to be correlated to the occupation of the 2t2g level of the d orbitals [6], the surface atoms pair potentials [7], the critical points on the valence shell of charge concentration [8,9], the bond energy model [10] or the sulfur addition energy model [11]. Nevertheless, the origin of such a relation is still a controversial point. However, in any case all the authors agree in the trend and form of the volcano curves which also evidence the high catalytic activity of rhenium sulfide compared to MoS2 or WS2 (as illustrated in Fig. 1 ). In thiophene HDS rhenium sulfide supported over alumina could be even better than a classical CoMo catalyst since Räty and Pakkanen claim [12] a conversion of thiophene of 82.4% as compared to 69.0% for a commercial Co–Mo/γ-Al2O3 sample. The catalytic promotion of ReS2 has been scarcely investigated. Only a few studies have been reported in the literature, but their findings on ReS2 promotion are quite different [13–15], as it will be discussed later in this paper. Taking into account all theses results and recent observations on the influence of sulfidation conditions over catalytic activities [16], it appears important to group and summarize all theses data. The objective of this paper was therefore to review the preparation, structures and activities of rhenium sulfide catalysts. 2 Preparation and structures of rhenium sulfides Rhenium sulfides have been studied by numerous workers and in a variety of disciplines, for their potential application as catalysts for hydrogenation and hydrodesulfurization, as candidates for secondary cathodes in batteries, and for their novel electronic properties. Therefore, preparations of these compounds have been attempted by many procedures, leading to different compounds and different structures, which are sometimes still debated. As regard to bulk sulfides, Traore [17] reported the preparation of rhenium heptasulfide Re2S7 starting from an acidic solution of potassium perrhenate and thiosulfate or H2S. After annealing under vacuum at 110°C during several days the black precipitate has been identified as Re2S7 with a quadratic structure [18]. According to these authors, this compound could be easily decomposed under H2 atmosphere to get an amorphous ReS3, which is the precursor of the rhenium disulfide ReS2. This latter compound has been also prepared by the same group under vacuum at high temperature starting from metallic rhenium and elemental sulfur. It could be considered as the most stable rhenium sulfide and has a hexagonal crystallographic structure (a =3.14Å and c =12.20Å), which parameters could slightly vary depending of the excess of sulfur [17]. Amorphous Re2S7 was also prepared by Hibble and Walton [19] by the reaction of potassium perrhenate and sodium sulphate in an acidic solution, and characterized by X-ray adsorption studies. Their results suggest the compound to be formulated as Re2 3.5(S2 2−)3.5 and the proposed structure is reported in Fig. 2 . EXAFS studies have been also considered by Schwarz et al. [20] for the characterization of ReS4, Re2S7 and ReS2. For both ReS4 and Re2S7, XAS data show the presence of S2− and S2 2− species, with S2 2− being more abundant than S2−; the authors suggested that the phases ReS4 and Re2S7 are closely related structurally. It was proposed that ReS4 and Re2S7 convert into ReS2 when treatment temperature increases, these two materials being members of a continuum ReS1.5−1(S2)1−1.5 structures that differ in term of their S2 2−/S2− ratio. Startsev et al. [21] reported the preparation of bulk ReS2 by sulfidation of HReO4 with H2S at 450°C. From Transmission Electron Microscopy examinations the sulfide appeared as onion-like spheres with ∼6Å interlayer distance corresponding to the interplane distance d002 of 6.1Å in the ReS2 structure. However, according to the X-ray diffraction the structure is strongly disordered. Spheres in the range 0.1–1μm have been also observed by SEM for ReS2 prepared from ReCl4 and Li2S in ethyl acetate [2]. In this case XRD data also evidence a “poorly crystalline” layered material. Indeed, even if rhenium disulfide has been studied by numerous researchers, its structure is still debated. Many investigators reference the work of Wildervanck and Jellineck [22] and assume that ReS2 is isostructural to ReSe2. That was reinvestigated by Murray et al. [23] which demonstrate that ReS2 has a triclinic crystallographic structure (a =6.417Å, b =6.510Å, c =6.461Å; α =121.10°, β =88.38°; γ =106.47°). The authors described the asymmetry unit of ReS2 mainly as a monolayer of nearly hexagonal closed packed arrays as shown in Fig. 3 . That could explain the layered structure observed by TEM but differs from MoS2 and WS2 which present the well known hexagonal geometry. For supported catalysts the rhenium sulfide could be also described in the form of spherical or layered structure and results of characterization founded in the literature are summarized in Table 1 . For Startsev et al. [21], Re sulfide prepared by decomposition of rhenium alkoxyde precursor under H2S at 673K is highly dispersed over SiO2 as small particles smaller than 10Å, which could correspond to ReS2 structure. For γ-alumina supported rhenium sulfide, prepared by sulfidation of NH4ReO4 with dimethyldisulfide, Quartararo et al. [24] also observed numerous homogeneous dispersed spherical particles with a size in the range 10–21Å and a medium diameter around 16Å. It was assumed that these particles are ReS2 but surprisingly no layered structure was evidenced. Seisenbaeva et al. [25] reported the preparation of alumina supported rhenium sulfide by impregnation of NH4ReO4 and sulfidation with dimethyldisulfide at 623K, and observed by SEM the formation of broad thin plate assumed to be of Re2S7. All these results lead us to believe that the structure of the rhenium sulfide obtained could deeply depend on the support, and on the sulfiding condition. That is in line of recent results obtained by some of us for alumina supported catalysts. As illustrated in Fig. 4 , for catalysts prepared by impregnation of NH4ReO4 and sulfided under H2S/N2 or H2S/H2 atmosphere, rhenium sulfide appears as layered crystallites with one up to three stacks, or as spherical particles in the range 10–20Å, the ratio between both structures being dependent of the sulfiding mixture. It appears therefore interesting to analyse more in detail the literature results to try to understand if some structure-activity correlation could be found. 3 Rhenium sulfide based catalysts 3.1 Preparation of catalysts Generally, unsupported rhenium sulfide catalysts as well as supported ones have been prepared using NH4ReO4 as precursor salt [4,21,24,26–35]. Occasionally other precursor as Re2O7 [36,37], Re(OC2H5)5 [21], Re2(CO)10 [12], rhenium penta- or tetra-chloride [2], HReO4 and rhenium ammonium thiosalt has also been used [3]. Supported catalysts have been prepared over γ-Al2O3 [12,24,26,28–33,35–37], SiO2 [21,27,29,32], or carbon [29,32,34,38–40]. Sulfidation of the impregnated precursors was performed on calcined [21,24,26,28,32] as well as non-calcined form [2–4,12,38] and was generally achieved in the 623–825K temperature range using H2S/H2 10% v/v, or CS2/gasoil mixtures. 3.2 Re versus Mo and W in hydrotreating reactions In the present review, the information about rhenium catalysts will be referred to their homologous molybdenum and tungsten catalysts because Co(or Ni)–Mo(or W)/γ-Al2O3 are the most important commercial HDS catalysts. The influence of the preparation procedures, metal charge, support and promotion of rhenium catalysts has been quite less studied than molybdenum and tungsten catalysts. Nevertheless, all these studies show that the unpromoted rhenium sulfide catalysts are more active than the classical molybdenum and tungsten sulfides in HDS and HDN reactions. For dibenzothiophene HDS performed at 623K, Pecoraro and Chianelli [2] found ReS2 to be 5–10 times more active than MoS2, depending of the preparation procedure. Such high relative activities of bulk sulfides were also observed in thiophene desulfurization as illustrated in Fig. 5 [2,28]. Due to the low interaction between the sulfide phase and the support, carbon has been considered by several groups as a good candidate to compare the activities of supported sulfides [4,5,38]. Indeed, Vissers et al. [5] and Ledoux et al. [4] observed the same relative activity between MoS2 and ReS2, the later catalyst being 3 times more active than the former in thiophene hydrodesulfurization. Such a superiority of ReS2 was correlated to a lower binding energy shift between metal and metal sulfide phases (compared to the molybdenum phase), which would preserve a high degree of metal character under sulfiding conditions. Interest of ReS2 for thiophene conversion could be also illustrated by the work of Räty and Pakkanen [12] in which conversions of thiophene of 82.4 and 69.0% were obtained for a Re/γ-Al2O3 and a commercial Co–Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, respectively. These results are in good agreement with those of Thomas et al. [28] for alumina supported catalysts evaluated in thiophene HDS. In order to control if the position of the ReS2 on the volcano curve could be different when another reaction mechanism is involved, as in the case of hydrodenitrogenation reaction in which ring hydrogenation always proceeds ring opening, Eijbouts et al. [38] have chosen to perform the HDN of quinoline at moderate pressure using the same carbon-supported transition metal sulfide catalysts previously prepared by Vissers et al. [5]. Excepted for the tungsten sulfide, the activity of the third row TMS were very high and a nice parallelism could be drawn between these results and those reported by Ledoux et al. [4] for thiophene HDS (see Fig. 6 ). Finally it is necessary to mention that although Ru, Os, Ir and Rh, sulfides are more active than Re sulfide in HDS and HDN reactions, the latter can be more attractive from applied catalysis point of view because its minor price. 3.3 Effect of the sulfiding conditions Prior to the catalytic testing the catalysts are usually sulfided using normally a mixture of H2S in H2 at around 623–673K for 2–4h. The sulfidation of Re2O7 to ReS2 by hydrogen sulfide and hydrogen at 873K has a free energy of −372kJmol−1 of metal, while under the same experimental conditions the free energy for sulfidation of MoO3 and WO3 are −221 and −110kJmol−1 of metal [41]. From a thermodynamic point of view the sulfidation of Re2O7 is therefore more spontaneous than the sulfidation of MoO3 and WO3. Nevertheless, it must be considered that certain sulfiding conditions could favor the formation of Re metal. Indeed, from temperature programmed reduction and temperature programmed sulfidation studies, Arnoldy et al. [31] demonstrated that crystalline NH4ReO4, unsupported as well as supported over alumina, is transformed to sulfide and metal according to the reaction scheme given in Fig. 7 . For large NH4ReO4 crystallites reaction 1 is the rate determining step and can be retarded by its products NH3 and H2O, though the reaction 2 would be the determining step for supported samples. The direct sulfiding of Re2O7 is the main reaction (reaction 3 in Fig. 7) to form ReS2, but the reduction of ReS2 to Re metal (reaction 5 in Fig. 7) and sulfidation of Re metal to ReS2 (reaction 4 in Fig. 7) has been observed above ca. 1000–1040K and below ca. 900–950K, respectively. From XDR experiments it was concluded that the interconversion reactions of Re metal and ReS2 are slow and incomplete, probably due to the occurrence of dense product ReS2 shell, which once formed hinders inward H2S diffusion [31]. With regard to the interaction between the precursor and the support and the mechanism of transformation of oxide into sulfide, the same authors [31] proposed that for supported catalyst adsorption and sulfiding of ReO4 − over γ-Al2O3 surface can occur according to successive molecular steps resumed in Figs. 8 and 9 . It appears that the stabilization of rhenium species on the γ-Al2O3 surface occurs by means of the condensation of ReO4 − ions with the Al-OH superficial groups and coordination with unsaturated Al3+ ions (see Fig. 8). The tetrahedral species I predominate in dry samples, while octahedral species IA and IB predominate on the wet samples. Species I are very reactive with H2S as well as with H2O. Removal of H2O from Re/γ-Al2O3 impregnated catalysts could be therefore of great importance to get a well sulfided catalyst. Quartararo et al. [24] found a degree of sulfiding close to 53% for Re/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, and Escalona et al. [33] reported a degree of sulfiding nearly to 90%, respectively for Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Concerning the effect of the nature of the sulfiding mixture, some of us have recently demonstrated [16] that sulfidation of Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with H2S/N2 instead of H2S/H2 leads to a higher activity in thiophene hydrodesulfurization (Fig. 10 ). For Re(0.76)/γ-Al2O3 and Re(2.75)/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, a gain of activity of 44 and 66%, respectively, was observed by sulfiding with the H2S/N2 instead of H2S/H2 mixture. The higher efficiency of the H2S/N2 treatment was correlated to a better sulfidation (higher S/Re values): S/Re ratios of 1.8 or 2.2 have been, respectively, obtained for a Re(0.76)/γ-Al2O3 catalyst sulfided with H2S/H2, and H2S/N2. The same behaviour was observed in the past for Ru/γ-Al2O3 catalyst [42], suggesting some parallelism between Re and Ru based sulfided catalysts. Therefore, the nature of the sulfiding mixture could no only modify the degree of sulfidation, but also the geometry of the particles, which could be associated with the existence of different ReS x phases. Indeed, Schwarz et al. [20] reported that rhenium sulfide exists as ReS2, Re2S7 and Re2S4, these two latter materials being members of a continuum of Re(S)1.5−1(S2)1−1.5 structures that differ in terms of their S2 2−/S2− ratio. In this case the S/Re ratio could vary between 2 and 4 without variation of the binding energy of Re. On the other hand, the specific rate increases remarkably linearly with the Re content up to a value closed to about 1.5 Re at.nm−2 and then increases more slowly for higher Re loadings as show in Fig. 11 . By comparison with a commercial NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst containing 2.75 Mo at.nm−2 and a ratio Ni/(Ni+Mo)=0.3, the specific rate of thiophene HDS over the Re(2.75)/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was about 1.6-fold higher than that of the NiMo/γ-Al2O3. In summary, fully sulfidation of the Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts cannot be obtained if the activation conditions usually used for Mo/γ-Al2O3 and Co–Mo/γ-Al2O3 industrial catalysts are applied, because the formation of Re metal cannot be absolutely discarded under these conditions. 3.4 Effect of the nature of the support The position of the maxima in volcano curves as reported in Fig. 1 does not change a lot if TMS are compared as bulk sulfides [2,3], supported over γ-Al2O3 [26] or supported over carbon [4,38,40]. This behavior suggests that the support has minor qualitative effects on the active HDS sites of TMS. Nevertheless, for molybdenum based catalysts support effect has been early recognized and some reviews summarize experimental evidences and possible interpretations of this phenomenon [43–45]. For rhenium sulfide based catalysts the strength of the interaction Re-support was founded to depend on the support used and decreased in the order: γ-Al2O3 >SiO2 >C [29]. That could modify the repartition of rhenium species over the surface and the amount of Re loss by a hypothetic Re2O7 sublimation during calcination [46]. In fact, for catalysts with about the same Re wt% the calcination treatment at 575K had a positive effect on the activity of the Re/SiO2 sample but very few effect on the Re/γ-Al2O3 and Re/C samples. Nevertheless, and contrary to molybdenum based catalysts, the thiophene HDS activity of the rhenium supported catalysts depended only slightly on the support used and increased in the order SiO2 <γ-Al2O3 <C, as illustrated in Fig. 12 made from the data of reference [32] taking the activities of the Re supported catalysts with about 5wt% Re. Higher activities of the carbon supported catalysts, as compared to the Al2O3 and SiO2 supported samples was explained considering the pore structure of the supports. In the case of Al2O3 and SiO2, micropores and mesopores are usually interconnected resulting in easy formation of NH4ReO4 crystallites in the macropores by transport of ReO4 − ions from nearby mesopores. In the case of active carbon, the abundantly present micropores as well as the mesopores are longer and generally not directly connected with the macropores [47]. As a result, ReO4 − ions cannot migrate during drying and only small crystallites can be formed. Carbon support would be therefore an excellent support to create small crystallites. However, the studies on support effect have been limited, and use of TiO2 or ZrO2 could be interesting taking into account the large variations of activities reported for MoS2 dispersed over these oxides [43–45]. 3.5 Promotion of the Re catalysts In the open literature, four papers reported the effect of promoter (Co or Ni) over the catalytic activities of ReS2, but the results are contradictory. Firstly, Stern reported in 1979 [13] that the Co decreases the activity of Re/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in the HDN of indole and α-ethylaniline, but has a synergetic effect in HDN of 2,3dihydroindole. In 1983 an antagonism effect of Ni-Re pair supported over SiO2 was measured by Rodin et al. [14] for thiophene HDS at atmospheric pressure. Recently some of us [15] observed that unsupported Co–Re and Ni–Re mixed-sulfide catalysts prepared by the co-maceration method exhibited a notable synergy in HDS and HDN of gas oil. The maximum synergetic effect appeared for a ratio Me/(Me+Re) close to 0.5 in both reactions and also for both catalytic systems, but the magnitude of the synergy was superior for HDS than for HDN, and varied with reaction temperature differently for Co–Re and Ni–Re catalysts. However, characterization of these catalysts by XRD and XPS does not allow to associate the observed synergism with the formation of a specific “Co–Re–S” or “Ni–Re–S” phase. With regard to the selectivities, the Co–Re system presents a higher HDN/HDS selectivity as compared to the Ni–Re catalyst, but in both cases this ratio decreases with increasing the temperature of the reaction, suggesting differences in the activations energies of the two reactions. For Ni–Re/γ-Al2O3 and Co–Re/γ-Al2O3 bimetallic supported catalysts, a promotional effect has been observed in the HDS and HDN of gas oil under industrial, like experimental conditions [48,49]. The maximum synergy appeared for a ratio Me/Re (Me=Co or Ni) near to 0.5 and 1.0 for Co–Re and Ni-Re pair, respectively. The HDS promotion factor defined as %HDS(Me–Re/γ-Al2O3)/%HDS(Re/γ-Al2O3) was close to 4.0 and 2.5 for Co and Ni, respectively at 598K; the HDN promotion effect defined as %HDN(Me–Re)/%HDN(Re) is 3.0 and 1.5, respectively. These promotion factors are lower than those generally reported for Co–Mo and Ni–Mo catalysts. In order to understand such a promotion by Co or Ni, Co/γ-Al2O3 (or Ni/γ-Al2O3) and Re/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were studied in separated catalytic beds Co/γ-Al2O3//γ-Al2O3//Re/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/γ-Al2O3//γ-Al2O3//Re/γ-Al2O3 in gas oil HDS. The promotion factor in these conditions was near to 2 and 1.5 for Co//Re and Ni//Re, respectively, at 598K. Taking into account that in these cases the formation of mixed phases cannot be possible, the promotion was related with the formation and displacement of an activated hydrogen, like spillover hydrogen [50]. This promotional effect in Co//Re and Ni//Re separated bed is in close agreement with the behaviour recently claimed for Co//Mo and Ni//Mo separated bed [51–53]. 4 Conclusions Unsupported rhenium sulfides appeared among the most active TMS in different hydrotreating reactions, and for alumina supported samples activities higher than those of industrial reference catalysts could be observed. However, these activities deeply depend on the preparation procedure and more particularly on the sulfiding conditions (as clearly demonstrated by changing the nature of the sulfiding mixture). That was suggested to be due to the formation of different sulfide phases, since spherical or lamellar structures in different ratio were observed. Nevertheless, structure-activity relationship is still unclear and more work is needed to understand that point. If the support effect in ReS2 based catalysts has been only investigated over SiO2 and carbon, it appears less sensitive than that observed for molybdenum disulfide over the same support. Moreover, promotion by cobalt or nickel could not be compared with those observed for MoS2, suggesting a completely different effect. However, all these studies have been done without paying great attention to the sulfiding conditions and complementary works would be useful for a deep understanding of these sulfides. coredata.dc:description: Literature data published mainly during the two last decades and dealing with the preparation, structure and catalytic activities in hydrotreating reactions with rhenium sulfide has been reviewed. These compounds have been particularly evaluated in model compounds reactions as thiophene hydrodesulfurization and quinoline hydrodenitrogenation. In both cases it has been observed that rhenium sulfide was among the most active transition metal sulfides (TMS) and sometimes better than industrial CoMo/Al2O3 and NiMo/Al2O3, the sulfiding conditions appearing to be a crucial step to get highly active catalysts as previously observed for ruthenium sulfide based catalysts. Interest in these catalysts is maintained for real feed in gas oil hydrodenitrogenation reaction (HDN), even if the promoting effect induced by Co or Ni is low compared with classical molybdenum catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Rhenium sulfide in hydrotreating
